name: 5-fluorobicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2546

name: 5-fluorobicyclo[4.2.0]octa-1,3,5-trien-7-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2546
Reason: The base molecule for prediction is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The bicyclic structure of the target molecule adds rigidity, which tends to increase the melting point due to more restricted molecular motion compared to benzene. This effect can be estimated as +30 °C. The ketone group is typically associated with an increase in melting point due to its ability to engage in stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonding interactions compared to simple hydrocarbons; a +10 °C effect is reasonable for the ketone. Fluorine substitution also could potentially increase the melting point due to the strong electronegativity of fluorine and the potential for dipole-dipole interactions; an additional +5 °C can be estimated for this. Summing these adjustments gives the predicted melting point.
